answers.answer:
Ukrainian citizens can enter Romania with a short stay status by presenting either a biometric or simple passport at the border crossing point. There is no requirement for a COVID-19 vaccination certificate or PCR test.

To find more detailed information, please refer to the summary provided and read under the section titled "Who and how can enter Romania? What documents do I need to present at the border crossing in order to enter Romania?".
answers.bResponse:
Ukrainian citizens can enter Romania with a short stay status by presenting either a biometric or simple passport at the border crossing point. There is no requirement for a COVID-19 vaccination certificate or PCR test.

To find more detailed information, please refer to the summary provided and read under the section titled "Who and how can enter Romania? What documents do I need to present at the border crossing in order to enter Romania?". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
For children or minors to enter Romania, all children from Ukraine are accepted. It is advisable to carry an identity document of the minor or a birth certificate.

To find this information on the webpage, look for the section titled "What documents do I need to enter Romania with a child / minor?".

You can find more detailed information by looking for the question "Are Ukrainian men allowed into Romania?" within the "Who and how can enter Romania?" section of the webpage.

No, COVID-19 vaccination certificates or valid PCR tests are not required to enter Romania from Ukraine, and you are also not required to quarantine if you arrive by land.

You can find this information on the webpage under the main section "Who and how can enter Romania?" and then specifically under the question "Do I need a vaccination certificate or valid PCR test for COVID-19 in order to enter Romania?".
answers.bResponse:
No, COVID-19 vaccination certificates or valid PCR tests are not required to enter Romania from Ukraine, and you are also not required to quarantine if you arrive by land.

You can find this information on the webpage under the main section "Who and how can enter Romania?" and then specifically under the question "Do I need a vaccination certificate or valid PCR test for COVID-19 in order to enter Romania?". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
To bring pets into Romania, they must be microchipped and vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian at least 21 days before travel, and then tested for rabies antibodies 30 days after vaccination and less than 3 months before entering the EU. All vaccination and antibody test results must be attached to the pet's health certificate.

You can find this detailed information in the summary under the section "Can I bring along an animal without a vaccination certificate?".
answers.bResponse:

All vaccination and antibody test results must be attached to the pet's health certificate.

You can find this detailed information in the summary under the section "Can I bring along an animal without a vaccination certificate?". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
Third-country nationals who resided in Ukraine and hold a passport can enter Romania through common border points and obtain a transit visa on arrival for up to 90 days. Those who were permanently residing in Ukraine may also be able to stay for up to one year by registering with national authorities for a temporary protection residence permit.

You can find detailed information under the sections "What if I am fleeing the war in Ukraine, but I am not an Ukrainian national?" and "I am a non-Ukrainian; do I need a visa to be able to stay in the country or register with the authorities?" within the provided summary. For further assistance, you can contact the OIM Romania team at 021 210 3050 or visit their website.
answers.bResponse:
Third-country nationals who resided in Ukraine and hold a passport can enter Romania through common border points and obtain a transit visa on arrival for up to 90 days. Those who were permanently residing in Ukraine may also be able to stay for up to one year by registering with national authorities for a temporary protection residence permit.

You can find detailed information under the sections "What if I am fleeing the war in Ukraine, but I am not an Ukrainian national?" and "I am a non-Ukrainian; do I need a visa to be able to stay in the country or register with the authorities?" within the provided summary. For further assistance, you can contact the OIM Romania team at 021 210 3050 or visit their website. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
Unaccompanied minors in Romania have the right to enter and stay, receiving support from government authorities and organizations like DGASPC for accommodation, food, transport, health, and schooling. They also have special rights as children, including the right to stay with family, and can report abuse by calling the national child protection hotline 119.

To find more detailed information, you can read under the sections "Can unaccompanied minors cross the border without parents?", "Arrival and assistance information for children and young people arriving from Ukraine", and specifically the sub-sections "I’m under 18, what do I need to know about my rights here?" and "I’m staying in Romania without my parents or family members. What kind of help can I get?".
answers.bResponse:
Unaccompanied minors in Romania have the right to enter and stay, receiving support from government authorities and organizations like DGASPC for accommodation, food, transport, health, and schooling. They also have special rights as children, including the right to stay with family, and can report abuse by calling the national child protection hotline 119.

To find more detailed information, you can read under the sections "Can unaccompanied minors cross the border without parents?", "Arrival and assistance information for children and young people arriving from Ukraine", and specifically the sub-sections "I’m under 18, what do I need to know about my rights here?" and "I’m staying in Romania without my parents or family members. What kind of help can I get?". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
Temporary protection in Romania is a special form of protection offered by the European Union for people fleeing the conflict in Ukraine, granting them access to social and economic rights. It is eligible for Ukrainian citizens and their family members, stateless persons and third-country nationals who had international protection in Ukraine before February 24, 2022, and foreigners/stateless persons legally resident in Ukraine who cannot safely return to their country of origin.

To find detailed information, please refer to the "Temporary protection" section in the summary.
answers.bResponse:
Temporary protection in Romania is a special form of protection offered by the European Union for people fleeing the conflict in Ukraine, granting them access to social and economic rights. It is eligible for Ukrainian citizens and their family members, stateless persons and third-country nationals who had international protection in Ukraine before February 24, 2022, and foreigners/stateless persons legally resident in Ukraine who cannot safely return to their country of origin.

To find detailed information, please refer to the "Temporary protection" section in the summary. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
To apply for asylum in Romania, individuals must submit their application in person at a border crossing point or one of the six Regional Centers for Housing and Procedures for Asylum Seekers. Asylum seekers have rights including accommodation, free primary and emergency medical care, access to the labor market after three months, and financial aid.

You can find detailed information on how to apply for asylum under the "Claiming asylum" section, specifically "How can I make a claim for asylum in Romania?". The rights of asylum seekers are listed under the "What are my rights as an asylum seeker?" section within the summary.
answers.bResponse:

Asylum seekers have rights including accommodation, free primary and emergency medical care, access to the labor market after three months, and financial aid.

You can find detailed information on how to apply for asylum under the "Claiming asylum" section, specifically "How can I make a claim for asylum in Romania?". The rights of asylum seekers are listed under the "What are my rights as an asylum seeker?" section within the summary. For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
Foreign nationals or stateless persons from Ukraine are entitled to primary health care, emergency medical care, and free treatment for acute or chronic life-threatening diseases through the national health care system, without paying social health insurance contributions. They also have access to national public health programs for communicable diseases and specialized clinics like Medicover, which offers free pediatric consultations and pregnancy monitoring for Ukrainian refugee mothers.

To find more detailed information, you would go to the website where this summary is published and look under the section titled "Do I have access to medical services in Romania?".
answers.bResponse:
Foreign nationals or stateless persons from Ukraine are entitled to primary health care, emergency medical care, and free treatment for acute or chronic life-threatening diseases through the national health care system, without paying social health insurance contributions. To find more detailed information, you would go to the website where this summary is published and look under the section titled "Do I have access to medical services in Romania?". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
Yes, children from Ukraine can attend school in Romania free of charge, regardless of their status. Options for higher education are also available, with some universities teaching in Ukrainian and tuition-free places offered to Ukrainian citizens for certain academic years.

To find this detailed information, you would navigate to the "Living in Romania" section of the webpage and read under the subsections "Can my children attend school in Romania?" and "Can I study in Romania?".

answers.answer:
You can exchange Ukrainian Hryvnia (UAH) for Romanian Lei (RON) at BCR (Romanian Commercial Bank) branches, with a limit of up to 1,000 lei per person, provided you have a Ukrainian passport. This exchange is done at the BNR (National Bank of Romania) exchange rate.

To find this detailed information, navigate to the "Living in Romania" section of the webpage and look for the sub-heading "How can I exchange UAH to RON?".
answers.bResponse:
You can exchange Ukrainian Hryvnia (UAH) for Romanian Lei (RON) at BCR (Romanian Commercial Bank) branches, with a limit of up to 1,000 lei per person, provided you have a Ukrainian passport. This exchange is done at the BNR (National Bank of Romania) exchange rate.

To find this detailed information, navigate to the "Living in Romania" section of the webpage and look for the sub-heading "How can I exchange UAH to RON?". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
Yes, beneficiaries of temporary protection in Romania may be eligible for a monthly lump sum to cover accommodation expenses for up to 3 consecutive months, starting July 1, 2024. This financial support is outlined in Government Emergency Ordinance No. 96/2024 and aims to assist refugees with accommodation during their transition.

To find this information on the webpage, navigate to the section titled "Conditions of the financial support program for beneficiaries of temporary protection".
answers.bResponse:

To find this information on the webpage, navigate to the section titled "Conditions of the financial support program for beneficiaries of temporary protection". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

To find detailed information, you can refer to the sections titled "Are there organizations that help the LGBTQIA + community?" and "My child has cancer and needs help, what can I do?" within the provided summary.

answers.answer:
Ukrainian citizens who have legally entered Romania and have not requested a form of protection can work without a job permit or visa, under the same conditions as Romanian citizens. If they lack documents for a specific field, they can provide a statement of training or experience, and can also register with county employment agencies for support.

To find more detailed information, go to the provided summary and read under the section titled "Living in Romania," specifically the sub-heading "What procedure do I have to follow to get a job in Romania?".

If you are a victim of abuse or trafficking in Romania, you can call 119 for child abuse cases, or the National Line against Trafficking in Persons Romania at 0 800 800 678 or +4021 313 3100. You can also report incidents to authorities, UNHCR, or the International Organization for Migration (IOM), and seek support from the General Directorates for Social Assistance and Child Protection (DGASPC).

To find this detailed information, you can read the provided summary under the sub-sections related to "unaccompanied minors" and "What else should I know?".
answers.bResponse:
If you are a victim of abuse or trafficking in Romania, you can call 119 for child abuse cases, or the National Line against Trafficking in Persons Romania at 0 800 800 678 or +4021 313 3100. You can also report incidents to authorities, UNHCR, or the International Organization for Migration (IOM), and seek support from the General Directorates for Social Assistance and Child Protection (DGASPC).

To find this detailed information, you can read the provided summary under the sub-sections related to "unaccompanied minors" and "What else should I know?". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

answers.answer:
From Ukraine, the official border crossing points into Romania are Halmeu, Sighetu Marmației, Siret, and Isaccea. From Moldova, you can enter Romania via Rădăuți Prut, Albita, Sculeni, Stânca, and Galați.

To find this information in the provided text, go to the section titled "Traveling to/from Romania and situation at the borders" and read under the subsection "Which border points can be used to cross into Romania?".
answers.bResponse:
From Ukraine, the official border crossing points into Romania are Halmeu, Sighetu Marmației, Siret, and Isaccea. From Moldova, you can enter Romania via Rădăuți Prut, Albita, Sculeni, Stânca, and Galați.

To find this information in the provided text, go to the section titled "Traveling to/from Romania and situation at the borders" and read under the subsection "Which border points can be used to cross into Romania?". For more details, visit https://dopomoha.ro/en/information

You can find this information under the section "Where to extend the validity of an Ukrainian passport in Romania?" in the provided text.
